qas.question: Which company adopted the ASA scale in 1946?
Beginning what year were cameras built with the ASA meter?
How did older models convert to ASA scale?
How was the ASA scale shown on models built after 1946?
What were recommended film values lined up with after 1946?

answers.text: they were now aligned to the ASA scale

qas.question: What company stopped using ASA in 1946?
When were the DW-48 and DW-49 models made?
What were models pre-1946 labeled with?
Who refused to create replaceable hoods with ASA scales?
What did the recommended film values no longer follow after 1946?

context: <a0_0><b5_0>General Electric<b5_0/><a0_0/> switched to use the ASA scale in 1946. Meters manufactured since February <a1_0><b6_0>1946<b6_0/><a1_0/> were equipped with the ASA scale (<a3_0>labeled "<b7_0>Exposure Index<b7_0/>"<a3_0/>) already. For some of the older meters with scales in "Film Speed" or "Film Value" (e.g. models DW-48, DW-49 as well as early DW-58 and GW-68 variants), <a2_0>replaceable hoods with ASA scales<a2_0/> were available from <b8_0>the manufacturer<b8_0/>. The company continued to publish recommended film values after that date, however, <a4_0>they were now aligned to <b9_0>the ASA scale<b9_0/><a4_0/>.
